title: Makin' Happy
text:
"Makin' Happy" is a song by American singer <a href="Crystal%20Waters">Crystal Waters</a>, released in November 10, 1991 as the second <a href="Single%20%28music%29">single</a> from her debut studio <a href="album">album</a>, "<a href="Surprise%20%28Crystal%20Waters%20album%29">Surprise</a>" (1991). It achieved moderate success in European countries, but spent one week at number-one on the US <a href="Dance%20Club%20Songs">Dance Club Songs</a> chart and also reached the top of the Canadian "<a href="RPM%20%28magazine%29">RPM</a>" Dance/Urban chart. In the United Kingdom, the single peaked at number 18.
Critical reception.
Alex Henderson from <a href="AllMusic">AllMusic</a> deemed the song a "highly addictive and enjoyable <a href="house%20music">house</a>/<a href="disco">neo-disco</a> fare". <a href="Larry%20Flick">Larry Flick</a> from "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>" described it as "a frenetic and hypnotic jam". He noted that it "maintains a similar <a href="deep%20house">deep house</a> vibe [as her first single]. Waters more than proves her songwriting talent here, while her unique feline vocals will test some and delight others." Andy Kastanas from "<a href="The%20Charlotte%20Observer">The Charlotte Observer</a>" complimented it as "a housy tune that's bound to, well, make you happy, what else?" Machgiel Bakker from "<a href="Music%20%26amp%3B%20Media">Music & Media</a>" called it "pop-house". The magazine also commented, "Just repeat the words Makin' Happy endlessly and you'll get a good flavour of '<a href="Gypsy%20Woman%20%28Crystal%20Waters%20song%29">Gypsy Woman</a>, Part II'." <a href="James%20Hamilton%20%28DJ%20and%20journalist%29">James Hamilton</a> from "<a href="Music%20Week">Music Week</a>"'s "RM" Dance Update wrote that "the strange nasally pitched girl is less <a href="Eartha%20Kitt">Eartha Kitt</a>-like for her follow-up to 'Gypsy Woman', a jauntly trotting repetitive canterer with some "ooh wee ooh wee ooh" (and a guy's "so happy") instead of all the "la da dee, la dee da"." Jonathan Bernstein from "<a href="Spin%20%28magazine%29">Spin</a>" described the song as "ebullient".
